Evidence Value (Analysis Tip): Contains ProductName, ReleaseId, and InstallDate. Essential to verify if the image matches the victim machine.
Identifies system bias from UTC. CRITICAL for creating a correct timeline.
Tracks run count and last execution time (up to 8). Proof that a binary ran, not just existed.
Tracks file metadata even if the file was deleted. Key evidence for 'dropped & executed' malware.
Contains SHA1 hashes and compilation timestamps. crucial for identifying specific malware versions.
Logs programs launched via Explorer (GUI). Shows run count and 'Focus Time' (how long it was used).
Created when files are opened. Reveals original file path, MAC timestamps, and volume serial number.
Shows recent files per application (e.g. recent Word docs). Good for finding accessed sensitive data.
Tracks which folders were opened/viewed in Explorer. Proves attacker navigated to specific dirs (e.g. 'C:\Passwords').
List of all USB devices ever connected. Contains Vendor, Product, and Serial Number.
Maps a unique USB Serial Number to its assigned Drive Letter (e.g. F:). vital for timeline correlation.
Contains timestamps for 'First Install', 'Last Connected', and 'Last Removal'.
Proves a SPECIFIC user was logged in when the USB was connected (User-specific hive).
Classic persistence. Programs listed here start automatically on system boot.
Programs run once at next boot then delete the key. Often used by malware installers/cleanup scripts.
Check for services launching binaries from Temp/AppData. Look for 'ImagePath' pointing to suspicious locations.
Review task actions. Look for encoded PowerShell or tasks running suspicious scripts daily.
Simple persistence. Any file here runs when the specific user logs in.
Maps Network Card GUIDs to static IP addresses or DHCP info. Links network logs to this specific host.
Deleted files. Metadata file ($I) contains the original file name and deletion timestamp.
Identifies Linux distribution and version. Essential for choosing correct volatility profiles.
Records SSH logins, sudo usage, and new user creation events.
Binary file (read with 'last'). Shows exact login/logout times and reboots.
Command history. Look for 'wget', 'curl', 'nc', 'rm -rf', or base64 decoding loops.
Search history and file cursor positions for Vim. Can reveal which config files were modified.
Look for reverse shells (e.g. 'bash -i') scheduled to run periodically.
Look for 'malicious.service' enabled to start at multi-user.target.
SQLite DB. Check 'downloads' table for file paths and source URLs (Where did the malware come from?).
SQLite DB. Check 'urls' table for visit count and timestamps.
Plain text file containing historical PowerShell commands typed by the user. Look for 'Invoke-Expression' or download commands.
Similar to Prefetch but for modern Windows. Tracks full path and last execution time of binaries.
ESE Database. Records network bytes sent/received per application over the last 30-60 days. Finds data exfiltration anomalies.
Stores chunks of images from RDP sessions. Can reconstruct what the attacker SAW on the screen (e.g. open documents).
The heart of NTFS. Contains metadata (timestamps, size, attributes) for EVERY file on the volume, including deleted ones.
